title: For Trade:  Ruger Speed Six 9mm
postcontent: Just putting this out there to see if I can get any kind of interesting trade offers. It's one of my most fun guns to shoot that I own and a fantastically trustworthy woods packer loaded with +P+ gold dots so it is honestly worth more to me than I think it is probably worth on the market in cash, so I'm not really looking for cash offers at the moment. However, since I have two Speed Sixes now I would be willing to pass this one on in trade for something equally interesting that I don't already have. The shooter in me would rather keep it but the collector in me is willing to let it go.It's a Ruger Speed Six in the very rare 9mm Para chambering. It uses full moon clips. How you feel about that is up to you. It's a bit of an inconvenience as far as high volume shooting since getting the spent shells out of the clips can be slow but in just about all other ways, it is an advantage. You can dump and load a fresh moon clip in this revolver faster than just about any speed loader making it an exceptionally good choice among revolvers for a defensive arm. Speed Sixes in 9mm are kind of a collectible that can fetch prices which sort of ruin it for this purpose, however. That's a way in which all the negatives about this example can be seen as positives. Its finish is quite ruined and was when I got it. I think someone stored it in a holster and while all traces of rust were scrubbed away, a light pitting remained. A distinguished whale colored gray patina filled it where the finish was missing like a poor man's parkerization.The good news is that the gun was utterly unnaffected mechanically, as were the very decent Sambar stag grips which are probably worth a good chunk of its value in themselves. The trigger is smooth as I think a Ruger can probably get. A Ruger is overbuilt like a tank and as far as function it as good as new if not better for being broken in compared to a brand new Ruger which takes a lot of trigger pulls to eliminate that factory crunch we all know. I actually quite like the way this gun looks from a utilitarian standpoint and unlike a pretty one in 9mm, you can kick it all around and not feel bad about it. Like I said it's probably my favorite shooter and knockaround revolver and I'll probably only let it go for a tempting trade. I'd estimate the monetary value somewhere south of $400 but for that much I'd as soon hold onto it, but again there are interesting trades in the same ballpark I'm sure I'd consider.
